Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2013 02:56PM 16Christine wrote: So proud of myself, had to write something. It's 2 am where I am, and we all should be asleep at that hour, right? But when I went to bed my skin started itching like crazy at the edge of the humongous dressing from Friday's simple mx. Tried to just loosen it, but was getting too near my one drain. The plan was to remove the dressing and pain ball at home during the BS office hours tomorrow. Could not stand to haul that big dressing around anymore and couldn't get rid of the itch. So I peeled the whole thing off, pulled out the 2 pain ball catheters, and changed the drain dressing. There are very helpful directions for removing the pain ball catheters at askyoursurgeon.com (they sell ONQ pain balls). And then I applied leftover rad lotion to the itchy spots, washed all the betadine (that orange stuff) off my chest, put on an XL tee shirt, took a pain pill and sat down to write this! Ahh, that is comfort. I'm very happy that I did this simple mx with no node dissection. My shoulder and armÂ  are completely uninvolved. Of course my new incision is more than a foot long and is ugly as sin. I would never make the scar project. But back, shoulders and both arms work more naturally now. I think BS must have freed up some scar tissue from previous mx. Her incision begins right at the edge of the old one. She seems to have left more chest tissue so the incision is not so tight as the old one. Of course the previous BS had to be sure to take out all the tumor without actually seeing it (sneaky lobular tumor masquerading as normal tissue) -- that's how I imagine it anyway. Icing on the cake would be to have some small LCIS foci in the pathology report to make this medically worthwhile. But the comfort is so much improved I'm glad I went for it anyway. You all having recon have a much longer road to travel. So maybe you need to protect the site but I can't imagine sending you to a store for a bra so soon after surgery. I always have more trouble with swelling where the node dissection was done 2 years ago if I wear even the lightest bra.

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2013 01:15PM 16Christine wrote: Thanks for this thread. Post-mx cording and scarring have been my worst problems. Good PT released the arm cords. It was rather dramatic -- PT worked on it for three months, then one day after the warmup (arm-cycling for 5 min on low resistance) I did a stretch for a few seconds, then suddenly there was no resistance. I held the stretch for a few minutes and skipped the other exercises that day. It felt great. That was one year ago and one year after surgery. I still have something pulling between the incision and the armpit but some of that is probably due to radiation and I don't really want to open up the "cancer side" again for a minimal benefit. Nearly full ROM is back, though I have little arm strength at full extension. My reach exeeds my grasp! Because PT helped, I'm taking a chance and having a simple prophylactic mx on the other side this month. I have a clear MRI so there will be no SNB, no lymph node touching allowed. I have found it very difficult to live with one large breast. I feel off balance and it can't good for trunk muscles. I consider myself too old for reconstruction and my best chance for a somewhat normal life is to go flat at home and have a couple of foobs for going out. Thanks for this wonderful site, and for this thread, which describes perfectly my experience/concerns so far. I don't post a lot, but I read a little nearly every day. Best of luck to all of you trying to find QOL after treatment. It is elusive.
